ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: We learnt how to build houses and how various structures were able to physically exist. We used a lot of maths, mostly resolving forces and moments.
I learned a lot about the concepts of making buildings stand.
Knowledge of structural engineering and how buildings stand.
I learnt a lot of information about structures and building codes.
I learned the physics and structural engineering behind why a building stands. Great background and understanding for architecture.
Developed thorough understand of structural physics.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: Good diversity of types of classes. We took a field trip to a construction site, had a guest architect come to lecture us, presented a building of our choice in class and even made pasta bridges.

Weaknesses: Not really a weakness of the course, but once the TA forgot to show up to the review session!
This course is not conducive to people who do not already know physics and math. The tests are all mainly math based, however the math is not taught during lecture.
Need much more direction and connection regarding what is important and the mathematical processes needed.

We learn a lot of really detailed information and also how they applied to the real world. Professor Hatfield did a really good job of making the class engaging despite the information-heavy nature of the information.  The review sessions were also very helpful and the assignments were interesting too.
I think some more time spent on mathematical problems in class would be helpful.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! This course is maths heavy but does not take the usual format of STEM classes. By the end, I had a clear understanding of the basic concepts of structures and we studied a lot of cool buildings along the way.
Taking the course for a credit D would be super interesting, but the material is extremely difficult to grasp.
I would if they were interested the topic as I think we learn a lot about structures in a fun and interesting way. If not, Im not sure as the course content is quite niche.
Yes. This is definitely a fascinating and practical class for an architecture major.

Yes, I would recommend this course to those with a strong background in high school physics. Background knowledge really aids in learning the content and it seemed much more difficult for those without this background.
